Chapter on Contemplating the Heavens, Part 29, Heaven of YÄma, Part 15

The bhiká¹£us, together with their companions, in the homes of donors, with the bhiká¹£us who previously knew each other and had precepts, with a deceitful mind speak of their faults and transgressions, or with a jealous mind speak of their broken precepts, or with a jealous mind speak of their lack of learning, or with a jealous mind speak of their deportment, and say to the donors:
This teacher of yours has broken the precepts.
Or speak of their laziness, lack of learning, lack of wisdom, and foolishness like a bird, with little learning and little wisdom.
Those evil bhiká¹£us speak such evil to other donors, always close to improper realms, where can they cultivate the practices of meditation and recitation?
They are empty and worthless, not firm or real, and when the body perishes and life ends, they fall into evil paths and are born in the hells.
At that time, the World-Honored One, TathÄgata KÄÅ›yapa, spoke a verse, saying:
Those who speak false words, afflicting all sentient beings,
Are always in darkness, their lives are like death.
The sword of words cuts their own tongues, why don't their tongues fall out?
If one speaks false words, one loses true merits.
If a person speaks false words, poisonous snakes are in their mouth,
Swords dwell in their mouth, flaming fires burn in their mouth.
The poison in the mouth is the poison, the poison on the snakes is not poison;
The mouth poison destroys sentient beings, and after death they fall into hell.
If a person speaks false words, pus comes out of their mouth,
Their tongue is muddy, and their tongue is also like a raging fire.
This is like a snare binding them, a messenger before hell,
Destroying the Dharma bridge and so forth, all are the faults of false speech.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
That person who lies, has no parents,
And is unable to uphold the precepts, will fall into the evil paths.
If a person speaks falsely, they will quickly be despised,
Abandoned by good people, and not protected by the heavens.
Not controlling one's speech, quickly becoming angry,
With a restless mind and speaking much, one will always experience suffering;
Constantly hating others, creating evil with sentient beings,
Using skillful means to disturb others, one will enter hell because of this.'
The Buddha, the World-Honored One, Kashyapa Tathagata, has thus explained the seven kinds of evil dharmas that hinder meditation and recitation.
Those evil bhikshus create harm for those who uphold the precepts, and therefore the heavens abandon them.
A knife grows in their mouths, and for the sake of little profit, they say that others' real merits are non-existent, and they say that others' real faults are non-existent.
Such a person is an evil monk, claiming to be a monk, speaking falsely.
Such a person always has evil intentions, evil conduct, and evil dharmas. The patron will later know and will think lightly of him, knowing his flattery.
This is the seventh dharma.
Therefore, monks should abandon this seventh evil dharma, namely, hoping for food and drink offerings, all wanting them for themselves.
Moreover, the eighth obstructive evil dharma hinders monks from sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures. Therefore, monks should abandon it.
What is the eighth?
Namely, collecting various precious substances and making various treasures.
Such a monk, fearing birth and death, shaves his beard and hair, puts on Dharma robes, and leaves home with faith.
In that birth and death there are many sufferings and afflictions. To speak briefly, there are two kinds of suffering.
Relying on the aggregates, sense bases, and elements, in the three realms, broadly there are five destinies.
Furthermore, the extensive suffering refers to the eight great hells, hungry ghosts, and animals;
the six heavens in the desire realm, within the desire realm there are also various sufferings of branches and leaves;
within the form realm, there is also mental suffering;
within the formless realm, there is the suffering of retrogression, therefore when about to retrogress, samÄdhi becomes disturbed.
Such a mind has innumerable kinds of discriminating suffering.

Having contemplated this suffering, the good sons give rise to disgust and fear such immeasurable faults, shave their heads and beards, don the Dharma robes, and leave the household life out of faith.
Furthermore, the Å›ramaá¹‡a also contemplates other sufferings, giving rise to fear, namely the suffering of the body.
The suffering of the body is in two places, namely the desire realm and the form realm. Wherever there is a body, one experiences suffering.
How does one experience suffering in the form realm?
It is because of fatigue in meditation that one arises from it. Having arisen from that meditation, the body becomes fatigued.
When they are about to fall back, their physical power and virtue are inferior, and the wind touches their bodies.
Such wind originally did not touch them, and therefore when it touches their bodies, they experience suffering.
Except for eye contact, which experiences pleasure without suffering, that is neutral.
Such distinctions in the experience of suffering are based on the physical body.
That good man, having heard this, knows that all the sufferings and afflictions in birth and death, the aggregates, realms, and sense bases, are all suffering.
'Having contemplated such immeasurable and boundless suffering in birth and death, he then goes forth.
Having gone forth, he associates with the unwholesome.
Because of associating with them, he engages in the same activities as them, and hears about the nature of treasures.
Why is he afraid of his nature and goes forth with faith?

Because he hears about other natures, he gives rise to greedy thoughts again, either hearing about the nature of gold, or the nature of silver, or the nature of treasures. Having heard this, he is insatiable and is burned by the fire of greed.
After burning, they will go with bad friends to the mountains, from mountain to mountain, from one mountain peak to another mountain peak, thus wandering everywhere in hidden places.
Burned by the fire of greed, they will always suffer day and night, without any happiness.
For what reason do they renounce like this?
Not contemplating that nature, they contemplate a different nature, namely abandoning the nature of the body, not contemplating as explained above.
That person's mind and thoughts are thus not correct. Because of the confused mind, they hinder meditation and recitation, losing good dharmas.

They are neither renunciants nor laypeople. Seeking nirvÄá¹‡a, they therefore renounce. Possessed by the nature of ghosts, they give rise to greedy thoughts. Bound by the snare of greed, they enter hell.'
At that time, the World-Honored One KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½Those who contemplate the nature of the body
Are contemplating all natures,
Those who wish to attain nirvana must tame the nature of the body, not anything else.
If one abandons the nature of the body and becomes attached to other natures,
that person is deluded about the true nature and will not escape suffering and distress.
The nature of gold cannot eliminate suffering and distress,
but one who truly knows the true nature will undoubtedly attain liberation from suffering.
All suffering arises from suffering, and this suffering is difficult to escape.
Wealth is feared by kings, thieves, and fire,
therefore one should abandon possessions as if they were originally nonexistent.
Abandoning them brings happiness, grasping them brings suffering.
Truly knowing the nature of the body and also truly knowing the characteristics of nature,
one delights in meditation and recitation and can burn away the mountain of afflictions.
Therefore, the wise observe the nature contained within the body
and sentient beings who know their own characteristics will attain the bliss of nirvana.

The wise person observes the nature of this body in this way, diligently and with a focused mind, not delighting in managing gold, silver, and so forth. This is the root of all fears for householders, let alone for renunciant practitioners.
For renunciant practitioners, everything is abandoned;
those possessions are all fears.
One does not attain happiness by selling possessions.
Such possessions are not possessions, they are non-possessions.
What are possessions?
It refers to observing the nature of the body.

If one abandons the nature of the body and delights in other natures - not being diligent in meditation and recitation - such a person, when their body perishes and their life ends, will fall into hell.

Therefore, renunciant practitioners should always cultivate the possessions of meditation and recitation, and should not seek ordinary worldly things, because those causes and conditions can increase craving.
Therefore, contentment is the foremost possession, while other possessions can lead to decline and distress.
This eighth thing obstructs meditation and recitation. Eminent monks should abandon it.
Moreover, the ninth obstructive evil dharma obstructs meditation and recitation for bhiká¹£us. Therefore, monks should abandon it.
What is the ninth?
Namely, being close to the king.
Monks should not be close to the king.
Why is it so?
Because all worldly people dislike and do not make offerings to monks who are close to the king.
Those evil monks who are close to the king hope for wealth and possessions, and always seek wealth and possessions in cities, villages, or places with many people, without knowing contentment.
If they do not seek [wealth and possessions], they merely approach the king in vain, obstructing meditation and recitation.
In this way, bhiká¹£us who wish to practice the path of liberation will return and enter the path of bondage. Therefore, bhiká¹£us should not be close to the king.
Moreover, what else should bhiká¹£us not be close to?
Namely, bhiká¹£us should not be close to evil people.
Who are they?

They are evil friends. Sometimes they become attached to the five sense objects, namely form, sound, smell, taste, and touch. They do not skillfully observe, are lazy and foolish, and dwell in villages and such. All of these should be abandoned.
Do not associate with any lazy people, do not associate with any deceitful people, do not associate
with any people who crave the taste of food, do not associate with any merchants, do not associateğŸ”½with any butchers, hunters, and others who make a living through evil means, do not associate
with any people who are naturally jealous, do not associate
with any people who hold wrong views, do not associate with any people who are not discerning, do not associate
with any people who are arrogant, do not associate with any people who have suddenly become wealthy and noble, do not associate with any people who gamble
for fun, do not associate with any people who sell alcohol, do not associate with any people who enjoy drinking alcohol,
do not associate with any places that sell alcohol, do not associate with people who enjoy seeing women, do not

Do not associate with the owners of all prostitutes, do not associate with all those who hoard miscellaneous goods and engage in commerce,ğŸ”½do not associate with all butchers, do not associate with all jailers,
do not associate with all bird catchers, do not associate with all frivolous people, do not associate
with all those who believe in non-Buddhist paths, do not associate with all those who are despised by the masses.
Bhikshus should not associate with such people, either living with them, speaking with them, or traveling with them on the same road. All of this is inappropriate.
Why is it so?
Because many people will doubt them.

If those who have left the household life or those who are pure and free from faults all should not associate with them, those who give rise to doubt will think that those bhikshus are also the same, because those bhikshus may be close to those people or live in the same place.
Such bhikshus will be defiled by the faults of others. Therefore, they should not associate with such people, let alone be close to kings.
The one closest to the king is the most vulgar and base.
At that time, the World-Honored One, the TathÄgata KÄÅ›yapa, spoke a verse, saying:ğŸ”½The bhiká¹£us should dwell in the forest,
not too close to the most vulgar king.ğŸ”½Wearing the kÄá¹£Äya robe, close to others,
like a slave relying on the master's orders.ğŸ”½The bhiká¹£u does not rely on others,
he should not even be close to the gods;ğŸ”½The goose should not be close to the dog,
because of its purity.
Without self, without desire, the mind does not seek anything;
One who fears birth and death,ğŸ”½dwelling in the garden forest, in the charnel ground,
on level ground or in the mountains,
is a good bhiká¹£u;
being close to the king is not good.
In this way, by various immeasurable means, one should avoid being too close to the king. If one is too close to the king, all practitioners of pure conduct will rebuke and criticize him.
The one who should be close to is only the wise king. Being close in this way is ultimately peaceful and tranquil.
By approaching the wise king, one will definitely attain nirvana, and wherever one goes, one will not regress.

Approaching the wise king has a method, namely, being firm and diligent in meditation and recitation, not engaging in other activities that interfere with meditation and recitation, associating with elders and cultivating contentment, one's mind being well-disciplined and always free from greed, and by associating with elders, inquiring at the right time, upholding and not forgetting, not seeking to see or hear rare things, and not giving rise to wonder.
Approaching the wise king has this method.'
At that time, the World-Honored One, TathÄgata KÄÅ›yapa, spoke a verse, saying:
Associating with elders and making offerings, diligently inquiring at the right time,
Cultivating giving, morality, and wisdom, and also associating with the wise king.
Among the heavens and humans in the world, the one who can show peace and security,
Is not bound by suffering in existence, the ordinary king of the world.
If there is no suffering and distress, this is called a king;
If one constantly experiences suffering and distress, one cannot be called a king.
The bhiká¹£us should be close to such a wise king, not to ordinary kings. Being close to worldly kings will hinder meditation and recitation.
If one does not meditate and recite, one will fall again into hell, hungry ghosts, and animals.
This is the realm of ordinary kings in the world. Therefore, the bhiká¹£us, knowing this fault, should always avoid being close to kings.
For one who dwells in the forest, being close to kings is not appropriate, and therefore one should abandon it.
This is the ninth principle that hinders meditation and recitation.
The bhiká¹£us, moreover, the tenth obstructive evil dharma hinders bhiká¹£us from sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures. Therefore, Å›ramaá¹‡as should abandon it.
What is the tenth?
It is said that bhiká¹£us hope for invitations and crave the taste of food.
Having practiced properly in the realm, they later go among humans, abandoning the delightful forest and wilderness, and roam everywhere among humans.

Thus, the bhiká¹£us are close to negligence. From house to house, from village to village, from city to city, from place to many people to place to many people, they roam everywhere thus, delighting in much speech, falsely going among people, delighting in worldly speech, delighting in seeing relatives;
relatives and acquaintances invite them together, obtaining delicious food and drink.
Having obtained various delicious food and drink, they falsely abandon meditation and recitation in the forest, negligently going, hoping for food and drink.
Because of always greedily attaching to various food, they do not realize the exhaustion of the body. Thus, attached to flavors, hoping for invitations, they take it as joy in their minds.

The bhiká¹£us, if they do not practice the Dharma in the realms, when the eye sees a good form, the mind delights in it and gives rise to defiled desires, hoping to see it again and again, and becomes attached to it.
In this and that place, the mind gives rise to joy.
In this way, the bhiká¹£us, while walking among people, lose their own benefits.
The practice of meditation and recitation, having lost this way, always hopes for the taste of food, and always goes to other people's homes.
Because the eye sees form, the mind gives rise to delight. In this way, in sequence, the ear hears sounds and the mind gives rise to delight;
the nose smells fragrances and the mind gives rise to delight.
In this way, delighting and becoming attached to all realms, one is bound by all fetters, bound by all snares, and follows after all desires. Not being a layperson, yet not being a renunciant either.
Such a person, when the body perishes and life ends, falls into a bad realm and is born in hell.
Therefore, one should not enjoy being invited by others, because enjoying being invited by others has such faults.
Therefore, bhiká¹£us should observe these faults and should not always wander among people.
If there is a need to go, there are five reasons for which one may go among people:
First, for the sake of a sick person seeking medicine and supplies, one may go among people.
Second, for the sake of benefiting one's superiors, one may go among people.
Third, for the sake of repairing a damaged Buddha stupa or one's own dwelling, one may go among people.
Fourth, for the sake of benefiting sentient beings, one may go among people.
Fifth, for the sake of saving the life of a king whose country has been destroyed by another king and converting that king, one may go among people.
For such reasons, one may go among people. If one goes among people without these five kinds of reasons, it is a false practice that interferes with meditation and recitation.

One who practices like this will not be liberated from old age, sickness, death, sorrow, lamentation, suffering, distress, or mental anguish. Such a bad monk, who claims to be a monk, is merely pretending to be a renunciant.

Therefore, monks, if one's mind aspires to cut off craving, one's mind should contemplate correctly, calm the senses, rely on the elders, be close to the Three Jewels, and practice with a focused mind.
By embracing the Three Jewels, one uproots all the roots of afflictions and latent tendencies.'
At that time, the World-Honored One, Kashyapa Tathagata, spoke a verse, saying:
Abandoning the practice of meditation and recitation, only greedy for the taste of food,
Such a one is not a monk, their mind like a hungry ghost.
Apart from meditation, there is no joy, so say the wise;
Apart from the joy of meditation, there is no joy to be found.
The fool abandons the joy of meditation, only greedy for various tastes,
Such a foolish and evil person will then experience decline and distress.
If a person delights in sense objects and always relies on the pleasure of sense objects,
They will increase unwholesome dharmas and fall into evil destinies upon death.
If a person abandons meditation and recitation, and gives up upholding precepts and generosity,
Being obstinate and untamed, they may have life but it is as if dead.
If one has already practiced in accordance with the Dharma, they will not die in the world;
If one is always foolish and ignorant, apart from the Dharma, they may have life but it is as if dead.
Although covered by human skin, the foolish are the same as animals,
Because the light of the lamp of wisdom does not illuminate their minds.
If one upholds the precepts, one can be called a human;
All those who break the precepts are no different from dogs.
If one is greedy and does not give in charity, and evil conduct is not tamed,
One is not called a human, but is included in the number of hungry ghosts.
If a person has neither precepts nor wisdom, nor the treasure of giving,
Even if that person has life, it is no different from death.
If one practices precepts, giving, and meditation, and upholds the mindfulness samÄdhi,
That person is also called a human, and should be revered by the gods.
A person with merit is a person, one without merit is like a sheep.
One with merit who knows merit, that person is called a god.
Thus, one with merit knows merit.
A person with merit is happy everywhere;
If one is without merit, one always suffers.
Therefore, a bhiká¹£u, having heard such excellent merit, should not be greedy for flavors.
This tenth dharma obstructs meditation and recitation. A Å›ramaá¹‡a who fears birth and death should be afraid of it.
Moreover, the eleventh obstructive evil dharma obstructs bhiká¹£us' sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures. Therefore, Å›ramaá¹‡as should abandon it.
The eleventh is when a foolish bhiká¹£u, due to a mind of self-conceit, does not ask others, does not open up his inner knowledge, and speaks to others externally, saying he is omniscient:
There is omniscience, and therefore I can speak, I can understand the meaning, I can read and recite.
All the aggregates of dharmas are what I uphold.
Hundreds of thousands of Dharma meanings, I teach to my disciples.
There is no one else who is equal to me.
He accepts it in his own mind and also speaks like this to others.

He only has the conceit of knowledge but is actually without knowledge. That person always speaks of his own merits to all sentient beings. Therefore, all those who hear in the world give rise to reverence. All the people in the world say:
This good bhiká¹£u is endowed with omniscience. There is no bhiká¹£u who is equal to him.

All worldly people say this, but that bhiká¹£u is the most ignorant, empty within and without understanding, with nothing in his mind like an empty vessel, also like autumn clouds, apart from meditation and recitation, and is worshipped by those of little wisdom.

Only by cultivating meditation, recitation, precepts, giving, diligently practicing, relying on good dharmas, wisdom, Vinaya, adorning with self-control, abiding in the Buddha's teachings, diligently without rest, and permeating the mind with great compassion, is this the Dharma that Å›ramaá¹‡as should practice.
That evil bhiká¹£u is empty within and without wisdom, and thinks like this:
If I now see that bhiká¹£u, he will show me the Dharma.
Such a bhiká¹£u will despise me. The laypeople always offer alms to me. If I study with him, they will not offer alms to me and despise me.
Therefore, I will now explain to others according to my own understanding and knowledge, whether they understand or not, I will not learn from them.
In this way, due to fear of being looked down upon by others, with a mind of arrogance, not understanding oneself, not asking others, fearing being looked down upon by others.
' A person with such an arrogant mind and false speech loses the five precepts.
What are the five?
Namely, false speech.
Because they do not know, they speak falsely for others. This is their breaking of the first precept.
' Furthermore, they break the second precept, namely stealing.
They should not accept offerings from others. The donors give offerings for the sake of wisdom, but those foolish people, with little wisdom, take their things.
Such foolish people are thieves. This is called breaking the second precept.
The third precept is also broken. The precept is that a monk who has just left home should rely on the precepts and abide by them. He should think like this:
I have now left home.
But if that monk does not study, how can he uphold the precepts? He may say to others:
I know a lot.
This is called breaking the third precept.
The fourth precept is also broken. The precept is about difficult questions.
Fearing others' contempt, he slanders the Dharma and says what is not the Dharma is the Dharma. This is the first precept that is broken.
This is called breaking the fourth precept.
The fifth precept is also broken. The precept is that because that person does not understand the Dharma, he says what the Dharma practitioners say is not the Dharma and says:
All of you do not understand the profound Dharma. What you say is not spoken by the Buddha.
That person thus slanders the Saá¹…gha, saying:
Only I understand, you all do not understand.
Thus slandering the Saá¹…gha, fearing others' contempt, he says to the Saá¹…gha:
What you say is not the Dharma.
But what the Saá¹…gha says is actually the Dharma.
That evil bhiká¹£u thus loses the merit of the true Dharma, commits the greatest lie, and upon the dissolution of the body and the end of life falls into a bad realm, into the hells.
Because of not asking others, due to evil karma.
Not asking others has another great fault, namely, the mind of arrogance.
Because of the mind of arrogance, he does not enter the forest, fearing others' contempt. He does not ask those who show the way:
What is the path?
How does the mind engage?
What is the object of engagement?
How can it be forgotten and still be included in the mind?

In this way, without requesting or asking others, due to the fault of a haughty mind, they are unable to attain such a path, so their minds become weary. Sitting in full lotus posture, they immediately get up again and think like this:
This Dharma is false, and those bhiká¹£us are vainly engaged in this practice.
This is not the path. There is truly no dhyÄna, no samÄdhi, no fruits of dhyÄna, no fruits of samÄdhi.
With a mind of self-conceit, fearing the contempt of others, they slander in this way.
Those with wrong views, when their bodies perish and their lives end, fall into evil destinies and are born in the hells.
' At that time, the World-Honored One KÄÅ›yapa TathÄgata spoke a verse, saying:
'Knowing the time, leaving self-conceit, requesting the elders,
The bhiká¹£us diligently practicing will quickly attain nirvÄá¹‡a.
All that is heard from others, they explain to others,
Knowing oneself to be free from arrogance, that bhiká¹£u truly understands.
Free from arrogance and great arrogance, knowing the path and the non-path,
Knowing oneself and others in this way, that contented bhiká¹£u.
The mind of arrogance is very firm, the mind is agitated and dull,
Aspiring for wealth, profit, and offerings, one will not attain tranquility.
' He does not ask others in this way because of arrogance, his mind is firm, and he is unable to meditate and recite.
In this way, a bhiká¹£u always eats the food of others to sustain his life.
He only has the appearance and robes of a bhiká¹£u, the name of a bhiká¹£u, and when his body perishes and his life ends, he falls into a bad realm and is born in hell.
Or because of the arrogance of the mind, he does not ask others.
Therefore, a practitioner, as long as his life is not over, always asks others.
In this way, a bhiká¹£u is always at peace in his mind. When his body perishes and his life ends, he is born in a good realm, among the celestial worlds.
Having been born there, they will subsequently attain nirvana, because they are free from arrogance.
The twelfth hindrance and evil dharma that obstructs bhiká¹£us from sitting in meditation and chanting is:
The twelfth is delighting in many acquaintances.
Many acquaintances are called unbeneficial. Such bhiká¹£us only increase craving.
If a bhiká¹£u has many acquaintances, he will have many distractions, because he has many things to do, which distracts his mind;
because his mind is distracted, he cannot sit in meditation or chant.
A renunciant should be impartial towards enemies and friends, and should not even get close to one acquaintance, let alone have many acquaintances?
If one is lazy, one is only called a bhiká¹£u.
Because one goes to others' houses, when one sees with the eyes, the mind becomes agitated.

Because one sees forms with the eyes, the eye consciousness becomes different from before. The mind does not contemplate tranquil dharmas, does not think or observe, and the mind is not straightforward. One has much to say.
Having seen acquaintances, one then hears their voices, and the mind becomes disturbed by conditions, with different observations, and the mind is not tranquil;
because of not being tranquil, one observes non-tranquility, with something to rely on.
If one sees an acquaintance even for a moment, it is a hindrance, let alone seeing an acquaintance for a long time.
Therefore, an ascetic does not even have a single acquaintance, let alone many acquaintances.

If a bhiká¹£u associates with acquaintances, he goes from crowded places to crowded places, wandering like this, unaware that his life is ending moment by moment, and then he loses his share of goodness.
If he loses his share of goodness, he is most deceived by himself, and cannot even cultivate meditation, recitation, or reading for a single moment.
Therefore, a bhiká¹£u who studies like this increases attachment and love, and should not associate with lay acquaintances.
Furthermore, if one can bring future peace and show the path to nirvana, one should befriend such a guide, a spiritual friend, a fellow practitioner of meditation.
What is meant by a fellow practitioner?
It refers to the elimination of all afflictions and reaching the city of nirvana. This is the foremost excellent spiritual friend.
Other spiritual friends are actually enemies, not true spiritual friends.

Because they are not true, they are not spiritual friends. If one sees them, speaks with them, practices with them, engages in the same activities, and does the same things, it will hinder wholesome activities.
If in the future one obtains their power, then they are called spiritual friends.
If they show the holy life, cause one to practice, or teach out of fear, showing fear for the future - being born in hell, as a hungry ghost, or as an animal, they are called good spiritual friends.
Those who cause one to create unwholesome actions of body, speech, and mind and go to the evil paths, one should not associate with any of them.
At that time, the World-Honored One, TathÄgata KÄÅ›yapa, spoke a verse, saying:
If one shows the future world, they are a good friend.
If one can block evil places, they can also save from disasters and calamities.
Always speaking beneficial Dharma, benefiting the future world,
They are a good friend, acting as a friend and benefiting.
This excellent friend has innumerable kinds and innumerable distinctions, and speaks the Dharma in various ways.
Not by much food and drink, paying homage and entering the house, not by showing loving sounds, touches, tastes, smells, and forms, can one be called a friend. Such a friend is not a good friend.
A good bhiká¹£u should abandon them and should not even associate with this one friend, let alone associate with many such friends, giving rise to innumerable faults.
If there is a friend who does not benefit in the future world, although called a friend, they are actually an enemy.
If a bhiká¹£u associates with such acquaintances, it will interfere with his own practice of sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures.
The thirteenth hindrance and evil dharma that interferes with a bhiká¹£u's sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures, therefore, a Å›ramaá¹‡a should abandon it.
The thirteenth is so-called a bhiká¹£u staying with evil people.
All bhiká¹£us staying with evil people will interfere with sitting in meditation and reciting scriptures.
Staying with evil people has five kinds. What are the five?
So-called a bhiká¹£u well upholding pure precepts, the foremost good dharma, with a sincere mind, but staying with the foremost evil person who breaks precepts, unable to be independent.
This is the first kind of staying with evil people.

Moreover, the second kind of staying with evil people is so-called a bhiká¹£u with faults of being not independent or independent, following evil-view people, whether in a village, city, or many people's places, going together and staying together.
This is the second kind of staying with evil people.
